conbody.p: This section provides the overview of the Charging application. For more information about the Charging application, see Charging User Guide in the NCC documentation set.
The Charging application allows for the charging and rating functions in NCC, and it does the following:

ul.li: enables service operators to control their offers and interactions with subscribers
performs the role of a Charging Function (CHF)

conbody.p: The Charging application uses Ro and Gy Diameter interfaces as native interfaces for charging, and for rating a session-based or event-based charging service.

section.title: Charging application components
section.p: The Charging application is composed of the following several modules that interact with each other.

This module encodes and decodes the Diameter Credit-Control-Request (CCR) or Credit-Control-Answer (CCA) messages. This module interfaces with the rating engine for context generation and rating response processing. The following are the sub-modules of Call controller:

li.p: This controller is responsible for external protocols, such as Diameter protocol, HTTP, FTP, and SOAP.

This controller contains the logic to be executed when an incoming Diameter request is received. It interacts with the other modules of NCC charging during the processing of a received request. It supports CCR/CCA, RAR/RAA messages over Gy interface, and SLR/SLA, SNR/SNA messages over Sy interface.

section.p: This module is responsible for managing the subscriber related information in the NCC database.
This module is responsible for managing the charging and rating entities in the NCC database such as bundles, tariffs and buckets.
This module is responsible for creating, updating and deleting call sessions from memory.

This module is responsible for selecting a charging service (from the set of defined charging services in the system), as well as rating and charging a call according to the definition of the selected charging service.
This module is responsible for providing framework for generating application CDRs in Abstract Syntax Notation (ASN) format.
